analytic.title: Toward durable and robust superhydrophobic cotton fabric through hydrothermal growth of ZnO for oil/water separation

div.p: In this study, an eco-friendly superhydrophobic cotton fabric (CF) with water contact angle of 155°was fabricated via a facile two-step approach: imparting surface roughness through hydrothermal growth of ZnO particles, and using stearic acid to create a low-energy surface. ZnO prepared by hydrothermal reaction was in a rod-like shape and had nano-or micro-scale sizes. It was located on the surface in loose aggregates. After modification with stearic acid, the aggregate structure of ZnO particles was changed from loose packing to compact packing. The superhydrophobic CF could be wetted by oil but could not be wetted by water, showing excellent oil/ water separation performance. The superhydrophobic CF was able to absorb oils selectively from their mixtures with water and could be used as a filtering membrane to separate oil/water mixtures directly with separation efficiency and oil flux of 96-99% and 2000-9000 L m -2 h -1 , respectively, depending on the intrinsic property of the oils. In addition, the superhydrophobic CF showed excellent mechanical robustness and environmental durability with water contact angle almost remaining unchanged after exposure to sandpaper abrasion, ultrasonication, boiling water treatment and organic solvents erosion. With excellent robustness and durability, the superhydrophobic CF exhibits great potential in oil/water separation even under some harsh conditions.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Oily wastewater from some areas such as textiles, petrochemicals, metal/steel industrials, as well as oil spill accidents has been seriously threatening our living environment (Gupta et al. 2017;Li et al. 2018a;Wang et al. 2015;Xu et al. 2015;Zhou et al. 2013). It is urgent to design and fabricate functional materials for oil/water separation (Caol et al. 2018;Dai et al. 2019;Gao et al. 2018;Ghobashy and Elhady 2017;Kang et al. 2018;Samadi et al. 2017;Sun et al. 2018;Wang et al. 2017c;Zhao et al. 2019). Superhydrophobic materials are one kind of the most promising oil/ water separation materials as they can selectively absorb or directly separate oil from water, due to their different wettability toward oil and water (Chu et al. 2015;Ma et al. 2016;Wu et al. 2018;Xu and Wang 2018;Xue et al. 2014;Wang et al. 2017a,Wang et al. 2017b). Inspired by natural superhydrophobic surfaces such as lotus effect, artificial superhydrophobic surfaces could be fabricated by rough surface structure creation followed by low surface energy modification (Bhushan and Jung 2011;Feng et al. 2002;Xu et al. 2017). Most of the reported superhydrophobic materials for oil/ water separation were prepared from non-renewable feedstocks and could not biodegrade after service, which would not only result in secondary environmental pollution but also lead to rapid consumption of precious non-renewable resources (Cheng et al. 2017(Cheng et al. , 2018a;Gu et al. 2017). Such principles for superhydrophobic materials design were not in accordance with the concept of sustainable development. Therefore, some biobased and biodegradable superhydrophobic materials have been designed and fabricated for oil/water separation recently (Dong et al. 2019;Liu and Yuan 2018;Phanthong et al. 2018;Shi et al. 2018;Xue et al. 2013).

Cotton fabric (CF) shows great potential in ecofriendly superhydrophobic material design, due to its various advantages such as renewability, biodegradability, good permeability, low cost, high flexibility and easily scalable fabrication (Chen et al. 2017;Li et al. 2015). However, pristine CF could not be used to separate oil/water mixture because it is both hydrophilic and oleophilic. Thus, superhydrophobic coatings have been fabricated on CF through various methods such as dip coating, spray coating and chemical grafting (Cheng et al. 2018b;Li et al. 2018b;Sasaki et al. 2016;Singh and Singh 2017;Xue et al. 2019). However, most of these superhydrophobic coatings were composed of non-renewable and nondegradable chemicals or even expensive and toxic fluorine-containing reagents, which negatively affect the sustainability. In addition, most of the fabricated superhydrophobic coatings showed poor mechanical robustness and environmental durability. The application of those superhydrophobic CFs was therefore restricted because they would lose superhydrophobicity under some harsh conditions such as exposure to mechanical abrasion, corrosive substances or organic solvents (Cheng et al. 2019). These conditions were usually inevitable for practical oil/water separation due to the complex compositions of oil/water mixtures from different origins.

Therefore, more recent endeavors have been devoted to design robust and stable superhydrophobic CFs for efficient and durable oil/water separation (Cheng et al. 2019;Guo et al. 2017;Hu et al. 2018;Huang et al. 2015;Lahiri et al. 2019;Wang et al. 2017a,Wang et al. 2017b,Wang et al. 2017c;Zhou et al. 2013;Zou et al. 2013). For example, Zhou et al. (2013) reported a polyaniline and fluorinated alkyl silane modified CF, which showed excellent mechanical robustness and environmental durability with oil/water separation efficiency of 97.8%. Zou et al. (2013) reported a highly durable and robust superhydrophobic CF by modifying the surface of cotton fabric with diblock copolymer of poly(glycidyl methacrylate) (PGMA) and poly(2,2,2trifluoroethyl methacrylate) (PTFEMA), which were synthesized via sequential atom transfer radical polymerization. Huang et al. (2015) reported a robust superhydrophobic CF by hydrothermal growth of TiO 2 on the surface of CF and subsequent modification with fluoroalkylsilane. Guo et al. (2017) reported a robust and boiling-water resistant superhydrophobic PDA@SiO 2 coated CF via copolymerization reaction and trimethyl silyl modification. Hu et al. (2018) reported a highly durable and robust superhydrophobic CF through surface grafting of glycidyl methacrylate and subsequent chemical modification with silanes. Cheng et al. (2019) reported an inorganic nanoparticle-free, durable and robust superhydrophobic CF through hydrothermal deposition of polydivinylbenzene (PDVB). Lahiri et al. (2019) reported a robust fluorine-free CF by deposition of H 3 BO 3incorporated SiO 2 -alkyl-silane coatings followed by polydimethylsiloxane modification. Although robust and durable superhydrophobic CFs have been successfully fabricated, non-renewable chemicals or even expensive and toxic fluorine-containing reagents were still not avoided during fabrication of these materials, which would also associate with resource and environment problems. Therefore, more sustainable and environmentally friendlier superhydrophobic CFs with excellent mechanical robustness and environmental durability are still highly desirable for efficient, durable and eco-friendly oil/water separation.

In this study, we report a sustainable, durable, robust and eco-friendly superhydrophobic CF through a facile method of hydrothermal growth of ZnO particles on CF and subsequent modification with stearic acid (SA). All materials for the superhydrophobic CF including cotton fabric, SA and ZnO are inexpensive, nontoxic and biodegradable (Bhadani et al. 2017;Cheng et al. 2017;Kielbik et al. 2017). The superhydrophobic CF with excellent mechanical robustness, environmental durability and oil/water separation efficiency can be used as an eco-friendly alternative to the counterparts prepared from nonrenewable, non-degradable or even toxic raw materials in oil/water separation under some rigorous conditions.

div.head: Materials
div.p: Zn(NO 3 ) 2 Á6H 2 O (C 99.0%), Hexamethylenetetramine (C 99.0%) and stearic acid (C 99.0%) were obtained from Micxy Chemical Co., Ltd (Chengdu, China). Absolute alcohol, chloroform, toluene, petroleum ether, n-heptane and decane were obtained from Chuandong chemical plant (Chongqing, China). Cotton fabric (CF) was bought from a local store (Chongqing, China).

div.head: Fabrication of superhydrophobic cotton fabric
div.p: Superhydrophobic cotton fabric was prepared through a two-step procedure, as schematic illustrated in Fig. 1. Detailedly, aqueous solution of Zn(NO 3 ) 2- 6H 2 O and hexamethylenetetramine with concentration of 0.1 M was prepared, respectively, and cotton fabric was treated with ultrasonication in alcohol for 30 min to remove impurities before use. 40 mL zinc nitrate aqueous solution and 40 mL hexamethylenetetramine aqueous solution were mixed in a 250 mL beaker. Cotton fabric was added into the mixed solution and stirred for 20 min. Then, they were transferred into a 100 mL autoclave. The autoclave was placed in a 90 °C oven for 6 h to perform the hydrothermal growth of ZnO on the surface of cotton fabric. ZnO coated cotton fabric was taken out of the autoclave after cooling to room temperature and was washed with deionized water for 3 times. After drying at 80 °C for 6 h, the ZnO coated cotton fabric was immersed in 0.1 mol/L stearic acid ethanol solution for 6 h and was then taken out of the solution and washed with alcohol for 3 times. Superhydrophobic cotton fabric was finally obtained after drying at 80 °C for an hour and 150 °C for another hour.

div.head: Characterization
div.p: The surface morphology was characterized by a field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, JSM-7800F) at an accelerating voltage of 2 kV. The samples were sprayed with a layer of gold before observation. The surface elemental composition and mapping was studied by scanning electron microscope with energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDS). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra under reflective mode were recorded on an RF-5301PC spectrophotometer ranging from 4000 to 500 cm -1 with the resolution and scanning time of 4 cm -1 and 32 times, respectively. Water contact angle (WCA) was measured by OSA100S-T with 5 lL of deionized water droplet at ambient temperature. Five measurements were performed for each sample, and the averaged results were reported. The sample was adhered to a flat transparent microscope slide prior to measurement.

div.head: Oil/water separation
div.p: 100 mL oil/water mixture containing 30 mL water and 70 mL oil was used for separation measurement. For better observation, the oil was colored by Sudan red I. The superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF was used as a filtering membrane located between two glass devices during oil/water separation. When the oil/ water mixtures were poured into the separation system, separation occurred with water remaining in the above container and oil penetrating the fabric and falling into the lower receipting container. Several oily chemicals such as decane, petroleum ether, toluene, chloroform and n-hextane were selected as the oil phases. div.head: Mechanical robustness and environmental durability measurement
div.p: Sandpaper abrasion experiment was performed by placing the superhydrophobic CF on the sandpaper and moving it for 10 cm along the ruler under a 200 g weight, and this procedure was regarded as one abrasion time. The WCA was measured after every ten abrasion times. For ultrasound resistance test, the superhydrophobic CF was immersed in ethanol and treated with ultrasound for an hour. The WCA was measured after every 10 min. Solvent resistance was studied by immersing the superhydrophobic CF in toluene, acetone, chloroform and DMF for 7 days, the WCA of the treated sample was measured after every day. And the sample was taken out of the solvent, rinsed with ethanol and dried before WCA measurement. Boiling water resistance of the superhydrophobic CF was tested by immersion in boiling water for an hour. The WCA of the treated sample were measured after every 10 min.

div.head: Surface morphology, elemental composition and wettability
div.p: The surface morphology and wettability of pristine cotton fabric (CF), ZnO coated CF (ZnO/CF) and stearic acid modified ZnO/CF (SA/ZnO/CF) were comparatively investigated. As shown in Fig. 2, pristine CF showed a smooth surface with some wrinkled cracks (Fig. 2a), which would be helpful for the adhesion and growth of ZnO particles. Due to the hydrophilic nature of the cellulosic fibers of CF, water droplet wetted the surface immediately when contacting with the surface. Therefore, the WCA of pristine CF was measured as 0°.

After coated with ZnO through in situ hydrothermal growth, the surface of ZnO/CF was much rougher with ZnO particles on the surface loosely (Fig. 2b). The WCA was also about 0°, due to the hydrophilic nature of ZnO particles. The high magnification SEM image of ZnO/CF (Fig. 2c) indicated that rod-like ZnO particles were formed through the hydrothermal method. ZnO rods from nano-to micro-size were formed on the surface of the CF. The heterogeneity in the size of ZnO particles was attributed to the presence of cracks on the surface of cellulosic fibers, which led to a heterogeneous nuclei formation and growth (Aladpoosh and Montazer 2015). In fact, the micro/nanoscale hierarchical structures were useful for fabricating super-wetting materials. After treating with SA alcohol solution, loose structure of ZnO aggregates collapsed. Instead, compacted particle aggregates occurred on the surface of SA/ZnO/CF (Fig. 2d), possibly indicating that ZnO particles were successfully modified with SA. Consequently, superhydrophobicity was achieved for the surface of SA/ ZnO/CF with a WCA of 155 ± 3°.

The elemental composition for the surface of pristine CF, ZnO/CF and SA/ZnO/CF was characterized by EDS, as shown in Fig. 3a-c. The surface elements of pristine CF were composed of about 61.6% C element and 38.4% O element. After growing with ZnO through in situ hydrothermal method, the new Zn element was observed with content of 20.9%. Meanwhile, the percentages of both C and O elements were decreased with the value of 46.1 and 33.0%, respectively. While, the ratio of C element to O element decreased from * 1.6 for pristine CF to * 1.4 for ZnO/CF, which indicated that the decrease in the percentage of C element was more prominent than that of O element, due to the fact that additional O element was introduced with ZnO during hydrothermal synthesis. After modification with SA, the percentages of both Zn and O elements decreased obviously to 6.5 and 22.4%, respectively. While the percentage of C element increased significantly to 71.1%. The ratio of C element to O element increased drastically to * 3.2 for the surface of SA treated ZnO/ CF. Such a change in surface element composition indicated that SA was successfully introduced onto the surface of ZnO/CF, since the content of C element overwhelm that of O element for the long carbon chained SA. The surface element distribution of ZnO/ CF and SA/ZnO/CF was further investigated by EDS elemental mapping as shown in Fig. 3d, e, respectively. Obviously, all the elements distributed on the surfaces of the both samples uniformly, indicating that both the growth of ZnO on the surface of CF and the modification of ZnO/CF with SA occurred successfully.

div.head: Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR)
div.p: Figure 4 shows the FT-IR spectra of the pristine CF, ZnO/CF and SA/ZnO/CF. The characteristic peaks of pristine CF appeared at around 3333, 2897, 1426, 1364 and 1026 cm -1 , attributing to O-H stretching, C-H stretching, C-H wagging, C-H bending and C-O stretching, respectively (Aladpoosh et al. 2015). The FT-IR spectrum of the ZnO/CF showed little difference with that of pristine CF. In the case of SA/ZnO/ CF, double strong adsorption peaks at 2916 and 2848 cm -1 emerged, which was ascribed to the C-H stretching of -CH 2 due to the presence of SA. Besides, new absorption peaks appeared at 1536 and 1398 cm -1 , which were arisen from the asymmetric and symmetric stretches of -COO-group (Aladpoosh et al. 2015). The results indicate that SA has been attached on the surface of ZnO/CF suscessfully.

div.head: Oil/water separation
div.p: It is well known that pristine CF is amphipathic thus could be wetted by either water and oil. Figure 5a shows that both oil (decane dyed by Sudan red I) and water (dyed by methyl blue) droplets could infiltrate the surface of pristine CF completely. The oil droplets could rapidly infiltrate the surface of SA/ZnO/CF, while the water droplets do not exhibit this performance due to the superhydrophobicity of SA/ZnO/CF as shown in Fig. 5b. This selective wettability make the SA/ZnO/CF suitable for oil/water separation. The oil/water separation capacity of SA/ZnO/CF was firstly evaluated by using it as an absorbent to capture oil from oil/water mixture. Two oils with density lower (toluene) or higher (chloroform) than water were used as representative oils. As shown in Fig. 5c, toluene (dyed with Sudan red I) floating above water was absorbed immediately and completely when it was contacted with a piece of the superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF. In the case of chloroform, it was also selectively absorbed by the superhydrophobic SA/ ZnO/CF although it was under water, as shown in Fig. 5d. The results indicated that the prepared superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF has a good oil absorption capacity and should be applicable for oil/water separation.

The oil/water separation performance of the superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF was further investigated by using it as a filter membrane between two glass apparatuses to separate oil/water mixtures. For better observation, oils were dyed with Sudan red I. Water mixtures with either denser or less dense oils could be separated with the same apparatus, as shown in Fig. 5. When the oil has lower density than water, their mixtures could be separated with an aslant placed apparatus (Fig. 6a). If the oil is denser than water, their mixtures could be separated with a vertically placed apparatus (Fig. 6b). Obviously, only red oils can wet and penetrate through the superhydrophobic fabric, thus the red oils fell into the under container. Water could not wet the superhydrophobic fabric thus remained in the upper container. These phenomena again suggested that the prepared SA/ZnO/CF was to separate oil/water mixtures efficiently. The separation effciency and oil flux of the prepared superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF were investigated to study the oil/water separation performance quantitatively. Several organic solvents such as chloroform, toluene, petroleum ether, hexane, and decane were chosen as the representative oils. As Fig. 7a shows, the separation effciency of the superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF towards the different oil/water mixtures was in the range of 96-99%, which was comparable to other superhydrophobic cotton fabrics, such as PA-Fe III @PDMS-coated cotton fabric (Zhou et al. 2017), polystyrene grafted cotton fabric (Li et al. 2017), HDTS/CNC/CESO coated cotton fabric (Cheng et al. 2018a) and PDVB coated cotton fabric (Cheng et al. 2019). The separation efficiency could not attain 100%, which is because that some oil was maintained in the superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF, due to its absorption capacity toward oils.

The flux of the superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF toward different oils varied in the range of 2000-9000 L m -2 h -1 , depending on the mobility or viscosity of the oils. The superhydrophobic SA/ ZnO/CF showed excellent reusability with unchanged separation effciency after using for 10 circles for oil/ water separation with toluene/water as the typical oil/ water mixture, as shown in Fig. 7b.

div.head: Mechanical robustness and environmental durability
div.p: The micro/nanoscale hierarchical structures of superhydrophobic surfaces may be destroyed during practical application under some harsh conditions such as mechanical abrasion, high temperature, and organic solvent erosion. The superhydrophobicity would disappear once the micro/nanoscale hierarchical structures were destroyed. Therefore, superhydrophobic surfaces with excellent mechanical robustness and environmental durability are highly desired for longterm application. The stability of the prepared superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF under various conditions was studied to evaluate its mechanical robustness and environmental durability. The mechanical robustness of the superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF was characterized by abrasion and ultrasonic treatment. The sandpaper abrasion was demonstrated in Fig. 8a. The WCA of the surface after moving SA/ZnO/CF on sandpaper under 200 g loading was measured to evaluate the mechanical abrasion resistance of the sample. Figure 8b shows the variation of WCA versus sandpaper abrasion cycle for the superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF. Obviously, the surface WCA almost kept unchanged with the value higher than 150°even after abrasion for 50 times. Figure 8c shows the variation of WCA versus ultrasonication time for the superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF. It is interesting that the superhydrophobicity of the sample was very stable with WCA higher than 150°even after ultrasonication for 60 min. Both the sandpaper abrasion and ultrasonication measurements indicated that the superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF possessed excellent mechanical robustness, which should be attributed to the strong adhesion between ZnO particles and CF surface of the superhydrophobic CF prepared via in situ hydrothermal synthesis.

The environmental durability of the prepared SA/ ZnO/CF was characterized by boiling water immersion and organic solvent resistance measurements. Figure 8d shows the variation of WCA of SA/ZnO/CF versus immersion time in boiling water. Obviously, the superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF exhibited excellent stability when exposure to boiling water with the WCA almost unchanged even after boiling for 60 min.

The organic solvent resistance of the superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF was investigated by measuring the water contact angle after immersion in organic solvents for several days. Figure 9 shows the variation of WCA versus immersion time in various organic solvents. Four organic solvents with different polarities were used, including DMF, acetone, toluene and chloroform. Obviously, the superhydrophobicity remained after immersion in all the solvents for at least 7 days with the WCA greater than 150°regardless of the type of solvents, which indicated that the superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF was very stable in the presence of various organic solvents.

The above results indicate that the superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF exhibited excellent mechanical robustness and environmental durability, due to the outstanding stability of hydrothermally synthesized micro/nanoscale hierarchical structures toward various extreme conditions as well as the strong adhesion between CF substrate and SA modified ZnO particles. With excellent mechanical robustness and environmental durability, the superhydrophobic SA/ZnO/CF could be used for durable and long-term application in oil/water separation even under some extreme conditions.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In summary, an eco-friendly superhydrophobic cotton fabric with water contact angle of 155°was successfully prepared via a facile two-step approach of constructing rough surface via hydrothermal growth of ZnO nano/micro-particles followed by low energy modification with stearic acid. The superhydrophobic cotton fabric showed excellent oil/water separation performance. It could be used as an absorbent material to selectively absorb oils from their mixtures with water no matter the oils were above or under water. Furthermore, it could also be used as a filtering membrane to separate oil/water mixtures directly with separation efficiency of higher than 96% and flux in the range of 2000-9000 L m -2 h -1 , depending on the intrinsic property of oils. The superhydrophobic CF showed stable recyclability with separation efficiency keeping unchanged after reusing for several times. In addition, the superhydrophobic CF showed excellent mechanical robustness without losing superhydrophobicity after sandpaper abrasion for 50 times and ultrasonication in ethanol for 60 min, and it also exhibited excellent environmental durability with superhydrophobicity remaining unchanged after immersion in boiling water for 60 min or exposure to organic solvent erosion for 7 days. The superhydrophobic CF with excellent oil/water separation performance, mechanical robustness and environmental durability could be used as an eco-friendly alternative to traditional non-degradable or even toxic superhydrophobic materials for durable and long-term oil/water separation.
